channel.title: Matt Herron
channel.description: Matt Herron is a creative professional and business developer that fuses product and technology development to rapidly concieve, test and prototype product ideas for any industry. This is a portfolio of example projects that demonstrate some of these prototyping case studies.

item.title: Hash#Track
item.description:
##Summary of Project This was a project to experiment with external APIs and various other things

Project Images

## Summary of Technologies Used - HTML - CSS - Javascript ## Live website *Add a link to the website only if it is live on the web. Don't add a link to something that isnt live.*

item.title: 4K Restoration
item.description:
##Summary of Project 4K restoration is a project that conceptualizes a fictitious company that restores and repairs vintage computers. The website was intended to demonstrate capabilities using technologies like HTML, CSS(3), JavaScript and jQuery. There are several instances of jQuery animate and usage of asynchronous JS to simulate typing on the screen from a vintage computer terminal.

Project Images

## Summary of Technologies Used - HTML - CSS - Javascript - jQuery - Responsive design ## Live website [Link to the live website](http://swimclan.github.io/project1)

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll’s dedicated Help repository.
